previewPlan.name: 2025 SBT GRVL - Red Course - Low Volume - 2:1
previewPlan.description:
Get ready to conquer SBT GRVL with our comprehensive 12-week Wahoo SYSTM cycling plan, designed to elevate your performance to new heights. This specialized program not only focuses on optimizing your cycling strength and endurance but also integrates yoga sessions to ensure you're physically prepared for the challenge ahead.

​

Our training plan is designed by our extremely knowledgable sports science team and is tailored to help you tackle the diverse terrain of SBT, combining intense cycling workouts with rejuvenating yoga sessions to enhance flexibility and recovery.

​

If you are in need of any technical help or want to know more about the training terms used in this plan check out the [Wahoo SYSTM Help Center.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenter)

​

Have a more specific question that isn't addressed in the Help Center? Head over to our [forum](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/) to see if your question has been answered, or just post it for yourself.

prospects.name: Warm Up: 25 Minutes
prospects.description:
If you're looking for a warm-up that will get you ready to rock your next race or high intensity workout, then load this one up and let the sparks fly! There are 3 main efforts right around and a little above your FTP to get things going, and a final 10-second long high cadence AC sprint to finish up and prime you for peak performance.

​

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Half Monty (Ramp Test)
prospects.description:
**Half Monty: The Easy One.**

​

We recommend this fitness test for:

- Newer riders
- Athletes with limited experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those who are mid-plan or who just want to get a sense of where their fitness is.

The _Half Monty_ 4DP fitness test is the most accurate and complete ramp test available. While it's not as comprehensive or as accurate as our main fitness test, _Full Frontal_, it's far more approachable and easier to pace for new riders. It also doesn't require any special preparation. You just need to feel relatively fresh.

​

Based on more than a year of research (and after dozens of lab tests and thousands of online tests) and using sophisticated analysis of power and heart rate data, _Half Monty_ is far more accurate and comprehensive than standard ramp tests.

​

It also tells you more about who you are as an athlete. _Half Monty_ provides you with your FTP, Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and Cycling Threshold Heart Rate (cTHR), all of which we use to personalize your workout targets.

​

If you're still using the 4DP estimates when you set up your account, _Half Monty_ will also refine your AC and NM estimates (but will not do so if you've done _Full Frontal_ or manually adjusted your estimates). If you want fully accurate AC and NM, as well as your Rider Type, Strengths, Weaknesses, and training plans adjusted to those Strengths and Weaknesses, you'll need to expose yourself to the _Full Frontal_ 4DP fitness test.

​

Ready to climb the ramp? You'll need the following before you start:

- A heart rate monitor if you want the most accurate results. Don't have one? Order one [HERE](https://wahoofitness.com/devices)
- Some kind of power device connected (trainer, power meter, virtual power, etc.)
- Be ready to pay close attention to the instructions in the workout
- Be sure your profile is complete and up-to-date (Profile > About You). Accurate information helps us make our calculations

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 1
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: P. Gaimon 3: Short KOM Training Session
prospects.description:
As part of his ‘Worst Retirement Ever,’ Phil made a name for himself by sniping Strava KOMs around the world. But if you’re going to travel around globe stealing crowns from some of the world’s fastest climbers, you need to bring your A-game.

​

In this short, 35-minute workout, Phil takes you through a warm-up on the famous Pacific Coast Highway before climbing into two short, maximal efforts on the way up Dekker Canyon. You’ll be in the hurt box, but be sure to pay attention as Phil drops his top tips for KOM / QOM segment success.

​

In between efforts, Phil keeps you entertained with stories about his Cookie Fondo, life in LA, a tour of his garage, a face lick from his dog and his personal recommendation for the best cold-pressed juice in town.

​

_Do this on: Day 3 of the 5-day plan._

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Tempo With Varying Cadence: 5 x 6
prospects.description:
Just as the name implies, this workout contains five 6-minute long efforts below FTP with slight variations in intensity and bigger variations in cadence at a generally low cadence every 2 minutes. Looking at power demands alone, you would not expect this session to deliver any real suffering and you would be right in terms of cardiovascular demand, however, the low cadence targets make muscular strength and neuromuscular adaptations the real moneymakers in this session.

​

Varying cadence ensures that your muscular system gets pushed hard without maxing out. Throughout the session, your nervous system has to switch between recruiting your muscles between moderate and high force all while keeping your HR and power just below FTP.

​

**Warm Up**

30 seconds @ RPE 1 -- 40% of FTP-- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

prospects.name: Endurance 1.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 4

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

**Extra Volume**

NA

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Open: 15
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for a more serious session. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the Road Race of The Hammer Series.

prospects.name: The Amazing Chase
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): Ultra-endurance cyclist Jack Thompson set out to ride the 2021 Tour de France route as fast as he could. 3,552km divided over 21 stages, his goal was to chase down the PRO peloton on his way to Paris. What would it take? What was realistic? What was possible? Follow Jack's journey as he battles the elements, the vagaries of the route, and intense mental and physical fatigue to arrive at the Champs-Élysées in Paris.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session, which is a very low-intensity ride. It's so easy that your power remains at or below 50% of FTP or an RPE less than 2.5, and your heart rate stays in zone 1 the entire time. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting (But not so interesting that you can't pay attention to the film).

prospects.name: Rue The Day
prospects.description:
Those who have completed SUF icons like Blender, Mini Blender or the Chores will be familiar with the 40-seconds-hard/20-seconds-easy variety of Pain Shakes that Rue the Day delivers in three enticing courses. While the first few efforts in each set will feel "easy," since these blocks are stretched out to 8-minutes in length, you'll be deep into the red by the end of each set.

​

While the efforts aren't continuous, they are long enough that you accumulate plenty of time near your VO2max, which is the goal of any MAP workout. Each 8-minute set gives you more than five minutes at 90% or higher of your 5-minute peak power. By the end, you're looking at 16 minutes of accumulated MAP efforts, so get ready to say 'Hello, Pain!'

Along the way, we'll give you some interesting mental tips on how to prepare for, and better manage, the discomfort (to put it mildly) that comes with such intense efforts. In the end, you'll be both a faster and a mentally stronger cyclist.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Demystifying VO2 and VO2MAX](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/it-takes-vo2-to-tango-demystifying-vo2-and-vo2max)' and '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: Big Gear Tempo/Sub-Threshold: 4 x 8
prospects.description:
This training session is about building up muscular endurance with four 8-minute long efforts at 80-90% of FTP at 50-65 RPM. The intensity is not too difficult, but when you add in the low cadence targets you'll be recruiting your muscles to push harder activating more of your fast-twitch muscle fibers than you normally would at these intensities.

The recovery between each interval is just 4-minutes, but you'll enjoy a higher cadence to allow the muscles to recover between each effort. This is a great workout to help build your fitness for sustained and repeating climbing efforts up steep mountains.

​

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Lake Chira
prospects.description:
Our first ever On Location gravel adventure and what a ride we have in store! This one may be short but it’ll have you hanging onto the edge of your saddle as we explore the Pilancones Natural Park, high up on a mountain ridge overlooking the Soria valley as we head towards Chira Lake. The goal of this ride will be to work on your good form with a slightly higher cadence than normal, keeping the legs supple and spinning. We’ll gently build the effort up a 3km climb to get the heart, legs and lungs working a little harder before descending to our final destination at Chira Lake. This workout is perfect for those days when you need an easier session or want to activate the body before going deeper.

​

This workout focusses on a progressive build through the duration of the climb helping with your pacing skills and sustained efforts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8773915186)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tempo High Cadence: 4 x 3
prospects.description:
The training benefit of this session comes down to the uncomfortably high cadence you need to hold during each effort. Even though these efforts are under FTP, the high leg speed required will leave your system working harder than usual for the required power output.

By maintaining the highest cadence possible (without bouncing in the saddle) you end up pushing your neuromuscular coordination near its limits in a similar way to Cadence Builds.

​

With an emphasis on low torque (high RPM) efforts this session is polar opposite to sessions like GOAT and Power Station. Even though these efforts are short and below FTP the high cadence places more of a load on your cardiovascular system, so expect your heart rate and breathing to be higher than normal for the power.

​

Since muscles can only contract (pull) any given muscle will primarily move a joint in a single direction. When it comes to pedaling a bike, your quads and glutes can push the pedals down, while your hamstrings and hip flexors pull the pedals back up (with the help of your glutes and quads on the other leg). If you were to pedal with one leg (as you do in Cadence Drills) and your hamstrings and glutes were unable to contract, once you get to the bottom of the pedal stroke your leg would be stuck down there. No matter how hard you might try, your glutes and quads will do nothing to help you get that pedal all the way around. Suppose you do have both feet clipped in, and you are letting your opposite leg push down to bring your leg back up to 12 o'clock. If your quads and glutes are still contracting (pushing the pedal down) while the glutes and quads of your other leg are starting to push their pedal down, you will end up with one leg working against the other. You must relax the glutes and quads of one leg to get all of the power out of the glutes and quads of your other leg.

This is where neuromuscular coordination comes into play. During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. By maintaining your highest cadence without bouncing, you are pushing all of the muscles in each leg to contract and relax (switch on and off) as quickly as possible.

While we give specific cadence targets in this session, everyone has a different limit to what cadence they can maintain before bouncing in the saddle. To get the intended benefit of this session you need to maintain the power targets at the highest cadence that YOU can maintain. For some that might be 105RPM, for others, it might be 150RPM. What matters is that you push YOUR neuromuscular system to its limits.

​

**Warm Up**

15 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 7 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

3 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- 100+ RPM -- HR <95%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de Tudons
prospects.description:
This session is a variation on over-unders, designed to elevate your MAP (maximal aerobic power) while keeping your cardiovascular system under constant strain. You'll alternate between hard MAP intervals and “recoveries” that are still above endurance level — forcing your heart rate and respiration to stay elevated throughout.

​

Set on the consistent, climb-friendly terrain of Port de Tudons, this workout encourages rhythm and control, with a focus on maintaining high cadence to emphasize cardio over muscular strain. The structure builds your ability to sustain high power outputs under stress, improving your breakaway potential and fatigue resistance without requiring extended time at VO₂ Max power.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/14035782507)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Across the Mountains
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): _Across the Mountains_ follows legendary cyclist Michael Cotty through two different adventures. The first, _Les Alpes_, is the story of Mike's non-stop ride from Evian-Les-Bains to Nice across the heart of the Alps: a journey of 677km with 17 mountain passes and more than 16,000 meters of climbing. The second, _The Road to Mont Blanc_, sees Mike tackle a 1,000 km non-stop journey across 21 mountains in the Dolomites, Eastern and Swiss Alps before finishing at Mont Blanc. Featuring never-before-seen footage and exclusive commentary by Mike Cotty himself.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Micro Intervals: 3 Sets 8/6/4 x 40/20s
prospects.description: If you're looking for a session with 40/20s efforts to build your MAP but won't completely empty your tank, this is 38-minute long session fits the bill. Similar to Rue the Day, this workout has 3 sets of 40/20s intervals to build your map - but each successive set contains two fewer repeats...though the increased intensity might make up for the fewer number of efforts.

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Bavaria: Oberjoch
prospects.description:
Saddle up and prepare to conquer Oberjoch, the signature climb of the region, taking us through Bavaria’s lush pastures towards Austria’s scenic Lake Haldensee.

​

This workout features a series of low and high cadence drills with a progressive intensity build. We’ll kick off the climb with a 4-minute low cadence interval at 80-85% FTP, followed by a 2-minute recovery. From there, each interval shortens by one minute, while the cadence and effort increase slightly, alternating between low and high cadence to maintain focus and form.

Once we reach the summit, it’s time to recover briefly before diving into the second part of the session: five 60-second tempo-to-threshold builds on the flat toward Haldensee. This workout is designed to improve aerobic efficiency, strength, and your ability to recover between hard efforts. Sounds simple? Let’s chat at the end—good luck!

​

The intervals will alternate between low and high cadence requiring you to ride at an exceptionally low cadence to stress your muscular system more than your cardiovascular system and then riding at 100+ RPM has the exact opposite effect with less strain on your muscles, but a greater strain on your cardiovascular system. Alternating back and forth between low and high cadence will ensure both your muscular system and cardiovascular system get pushed hard.

The tempo builds will work you hard but flush out your legs making your recovery quicker so you can go hard tomorrow.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9853644571)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Endurance 2.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm-Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 7

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set: 1

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <85%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Full Circle
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2021): From filmmaker / ultra-endurance cyclist Mike Cotty:

​

"For many of us, cycling serves as a means of self-exploration—bridging gaps between the past, present and future. The blend between mind and body, working together to overcome hard moments—be it physical, mental or emotional—and how we learn to cope in our own mind is essential in being able to process the past, be true to ourselves in the present, and create moments of inner peace in the future.

​

A decade after crossing the French Pyrénées non-stop on a ride that would act as a catalyst for change, I wanted to share this story for the first time. To give an insight into the deeper meaning behind some of the mountain challenges you may have seen me undertake over the years, I felt now was the time to head back to my mountains, return to source, and embrace the unknown.

​

Overcoming the mountains of our mind, from escapism to reconnection. 10 years, 10 cols and 10,000 meters of climbing. This is my story of going Full Circle.

​

Thank you for watching. I truly hope there is something in this video that can help you in your own journey.

​

Peace,

Mike Cotty"

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session, which is a very low-intensity ride. It's so easy that your power remains at or below 50% of FTP or an RPE less than 2.5, and your heart rate stays in zone 1 the entire time. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting (But not so interesting that you can't pay attention to the film).

prospects.name: Do As You're Told
prospects.description:
The little voice in your head is telling you to stop. The screams from your legs are nearly deafening. But you hear none of it. You're following orders to ATTACK.

​

This is the story of two men in a car—your team directors—who guide you to GLORY. Ignore them at your own risk: They will not tolerate insubordination.

​

In this session, you'll tackle two sets of 11 intervals each. The first set has high-intensity efforts with matching recoveries. This pushes your body's ability to recover right to the limit -- just what you need to improve Anaerobic Capacity (AC). The shorter, super-high intensity efforts also help with your Neuromuscular Power (NM). The second set features inverse intervals with opposite efforts and recoveries. This really depletes your body's AC, so you need to rely on your aerobic system. This helps develop your Maximal Aerobic Power.

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 4 Pt 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024):

**Episode 4: Setting An Example**

In Episode 4 we arrive in Steamboat Springs, CO and start to settle in before race day. We pre ride the course, pick up packets and find some nerves. In our final athlete feature we dive into what drives Kristen Myers? How does the super mom do it all and still find time to train? This episodes is all about the final preparations before race day.

​

**Episode 5: Mind Over Matter**

In our last episode, we reach the culmination of all our riders hard work and arrive in Steamboat Springs, CO for the SBT GRVL race. Do they have what it takes to finish 125 miles with less than 6 months of training? Each person will battle their own self doubt as the gun goes off for the final time this season.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Tour of Norway 2
prospects.description:
**Featured rider:** Carl Fredrick HAGEN of Norway

**Event: **Tour of Norway

**Mission - "Wonderkid":** Experience the thrill of the breakaway with the peloton breathing down your neck - You're riding for Team Lotto Soudal - You've been in the breakaway all day. There's just one hour of racing left and you're sitting at the top of the virtual GC on the last day of the Tour of Norway, your home tour — Of any day to go all out and empty the tank, today is the day — Take your pulls, lead the breakaway and fight to stay away from the peloton.

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: FTP/MAP Builds: 8 x 3
prospects.description:
This session packs a punch with eight 3-minute intervals, all starting at 100% of FTP, and ending at 100% of MAP. Not only is this a great workout physiologically, but it's also great for learning how to ride a negative split.

​

When we talk about a "negative split" we mean completing the second half of an effort at a higher speed/power than the first half. While the first few of these might not feel so bad, the repetition and 1:1 work to recovery will ensure your heart rate and breathing stay elevated for the second half.

​

As you complete each effort, holding 100% of FTP will feel harder and harder. This in itself is excellent mental practice for "feeling" how your RPE for the same power can drift up as fatigue sets in. Knowing what 100% of FTP feels like when your legs are nearly spent is a great reminder of why starting an effort too hard will bite you in the end.

​

This dishes out a respectable 24-minutes of intensity. The fact that your heart and lungs are already pumping at high output when you start each MAP effort maximizes the gain you'll get from those 8-minutes at 100% of MAP.

​

Regardless of your chosen discipline or event, this is a session that will benefit everyone, both regarding learning good pacing and giving your aerobic system a big training boost.

​

**Warm Up**

2 minutes 30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

30 seconds @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

30 seconds @ RPE 8 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort** x8

Effort 1: 2 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

Effort 2: 1 minutes @ RPE 8.5 -- 120% of FTP -- HR >105%%

Rest: 3 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Tempo Cadence Build: 1 x 75
prospects.description:
While the single tempo effort you complete in this session is steady in terms of power, it is the specific cadence targets that set this session apart from other tempo workouts.

​

Even though an effort at 80% of FTP might seem "easy" the truth is your body is working at processing oxygen and metabolites at nearly the same rate when you are right at FTP. The difference is that the overall stress on your system when riding tempo is considerably less than riding at FTP. That means you can either have harder days before or after a tempo session (compared to a Threshold session) or you can increase the duration of those tempo efforts to make the overall training stimulus equal (or greater) than completing several repeats right at your FTP.

​

This tempo effort is divided into 3 segments of equal duration. While the power is the same across all segments, your target cadence starts out low and increases with each new segment from 65rpm, 75rpm and finally 95rpm. Starting with a long block of low cadence should fatigue your muscles from the start of your effort. As the effort builds and you create more fatigue, the increased cadence targets will place a greater demand on your cardiovascular system. That will, in some way, feel like a nice break given the load you have been putting on your muscular system. The cadence targets in the final segment will force your fatigued muscles to maintain good coordination as the faster cadence requires your muscles to switch "on" and "off" at a faster rate. Between the low rpm sections, and the high rpm work under fatigue, this tempo session not only helps train your FTP, but it has a training benefit to your neuromuscular system.

​

You can expect your Heart Rate to remain low for the power targets during the low cadence segment at the start. As the effort progresses and you reach the final 10 minutes of the high rpm segment your heart rate might go over Z3, which is not something to worry about. While this session appears "easy" at first glance, don't be surprised if your legs are feeling it the next day.

​

**Warm Up**

25 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

Build 1: 25 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <80% at 65rpm

Build 2: 25 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <80% at 75rpm

Build 3: 25 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <80% at 95rpm

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.description:

Join four exceptional athletes in the Adirondack mountains on the adventure of a lifetime. These athletes challenge themselves, conquer fears, and demonstrate their ability to overcome obstacles, proving to themselves and the world they can achieve anything.

Witness Riley, a remarkable young man with Autism and Tourette's, as he pedals beyond expectations to conquer the challenging 31+ mile Big Sugar gravel bike race. This isn't just a story about cycling; it's a journey of courage, hope, and the shattering barriers. With the unwavering support of his mom and the dedicated team at Adventure For All, Riley's adventure redefines what's possible, turning every pedal stroke into a victory for him and everyone who believed in his endless potential.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): Discover the incredible stories behind some of this year's top Wahooligan athletes:

**Chelsea Sodaro** is the reigning IRONMAN World Champion, but beyond her athletic prowess, Chelsea's greatest source of pride is her ability to show up for herself and her daughter. Chelsea shares the power of finding her voice, advocating for female athletes, and why motherhood is her most significant victory to date. Follow Chelsea's journey to defending her World Champion title in 2023.

**Heather Jackson:** As one chapter closes, a new one opens. After 15 years as a professional triathlete, Heather Jackson decided to challenge herself in new ways, build a fresh community, and push her own and other's expectations of what is humanly possible. In June, Heather tackled the Unbound Gravel 200, often hailed as the "Super Bowl" of gravel bike racing, and the iconic Western States Endurance Run, the world’s oldest 100-mile trail race. Facing these demanding events with just a two-week gap between them, the question looms: how will Heather approach her most ambitious goal yet?

It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

prospects.name: A Very Dark Place
prospects.description: You know that ride where you thought you went harder, deeper, and to a darker place than you'd ever gone before? HAHAHAHA. prospects.name: Tempo/Threshold/MAP: 6 x 3-2-1
prospects.description:
This should be a key session for anyone who wants to improve their FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The efforts themselves aren't outrageous, but the short recovery periods and the demand to continue repeating them make this a challenging session. The main set of the workout contains six sets of:

- 3 minutes at 90% LT power + 1 minute of recovery
- 2 minutes at 100% LT power + 1 minute recovery
- 1 minute at 110% LT power + 1 minute recovery with no additional rest before repeating the set.

This is a tough session so focus on recovery after this workout. Stretching and/or self massaging, replacing your fluids, and eating a meal containing carbohydrates and protein will all help to rebuild the muscles and grow stronger!

​

**Warm Up **

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes 30 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes 15 seconds @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

2 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <80%

prospects.name: Endurance  2
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

Warm-Up

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

Main Effort

Number of Sets

5

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set

1

Interval: 10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

Extra Volume

N/A

​

Cool Down

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Omnium
prospects.description:
Do you know what we love about you? Your versatility. You can Suffer anywhere, anytime, and in any way. That's why Grunter von Agony, Sufferlandrian Team Director, is sending you to compete in The Omnium at the UCI World Track Championships. Over the course of 50 minutes, you'll do battle in the six different races.

​

No two intervals in this workout are the same, with each one working slightly different Neuromuscular (NM), Anaerobic Capacity (AC), and Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) variations. No need for FTP here, friends. It's the perfect session to improve top-end power without having to do a ton of repetitive efforts.

​

The Scratch Race and Flying Lap have an easy enough lead-in that you get to put your max sprint to the full test. Add in the standing starts for the Individual Pursuit and Kilo, and you give your NM a real run-through. The repeated surges of the Elimination Race, the all-out nature of the Kilo, and the massive efforts you have to make in the points race really test your powers of recovery while working your AC all the way to the max.

​

Since the efforts come in quick succession, and with most being over four minutes in length, your cardiovascular system never catches a real break, ensuring your MAP doesn’t get left out of the equation.

prospects.name: # Getting Away With It (November Groundwork Challenge)
prospects.description:
This workout is part of the Wahoo X Monthly Challenge. Click [++here++](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/t/wahoo-november-challenge-groundwork/30430) to find out more.

​

Wouldn't it be great if you could leave work to go for a ride? Even for an hour? Well, now's your chance. _Getting Away With It_ gets you out of the office and onto the roads of the French Pyrenees with your guide Michael Cotty of The Col Collective.

​

This is a great session to add toward the end of a training block. The shorter duration, sub-threshold efforts are fantastic for getting some extra FTP building while you are in a fatigued state. Extra emphasis on cadence stresses your nervous system, making your body more efficient at higher and lower RPMs while improving your form. The Neuromuscular training you get from this session is fantastic, so while your power never exceeds threshold, your body will learn to bring more energy to the pedals at all intensities.

prospects.name: Classic Climbs of France: Col de Braus
prospects.description:
The Col de Braus workout focuses on maintaining a consistent tempo while responding to varied efforts, mimicking real race scenarios. This dynamic training session designed to build endurance and power with a series of specific tempo and surge efforts starts out with a steady tempo pace. At the 2 km mark, we will engage in a 90-second effort as if responding to a breakaway, then return to a strong threshold pace as the profile dips. Throughout the ride, the focus will be on maintaining a high tempo, incorporating ten 3-minute efforts with 30-second out-of-the-saddle bursts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/11556448551)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Sprints: 12 x 10s
prospects.description:
This is a session that you'll want to complete in Level, rather than Erg, mode. The only time we would suggest Erg mode is if you are unable to maintain the lower power targets set between sprints.

With short maximal sprint efforts, you'll recruit every muscle fiber you have in your legs with each effort. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal force. Just like cadence builds this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system. Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down effect to the longer duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

This session is a great alternate to cadence builds or standing starts for those completing our SUF Strength sessions. On days you complete off the bike strength work you want your on bike training to complement the suffering you put yourself through off the bike. That means short maximal efforts (whether for power or for cadence) are the best workouts to complement the strength gains you've made off the bike.

As long as you run this session in slope mode you can complete the sprints either seated or out of the saddle. For those competing in events that do not require much (if any) standing (such as Time Trials or Triathlons) you should complete these sprints seated (and in the aerobars or drops if that is where you are racing).

You should also do these efforts seated if you don't feel an out-of-the-saddle maximal sprint is stable/safe to do on your trainer. Regardless of using ERG or Slope mode, you do not want to hold anything back on any sprint. Seeing your peak power drop as the session goes on is totally normal as your legs fatigue. This is where RPE really becomes the most important metric, rather than power, heart rate, or cadence.

Now get on that bike and CRUSH IT!

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 12

Rest between sets: 9 minutes 50 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: NA

**Interval**

10 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 200% of FTP -- >105%

**Extra Volume**

N/A

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 1
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: Cadence Drills (Builds/Holds/Single Leg)
prospects.description:
This workout combines several technique driven intervals. These will improve your overall form and efficiency on the bike. The first two drills, Cadence Holds and Builds, are designed to improve the way you recruit your leg, glute and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke. They do this by forcing you to sustain a cadence just above 'comfortable' and by pushing you to your maximal cadence.

​

The last drill, Single Leg Efforts, ask you to unclip one leg and ride at a steady, single-legged effort. This forces you to pull up on the pedal instead of just pushing down and ensures maximal muscle awareness and engagement. This workout is best done while riding indoors on a trainer because even small variations in terrain can affect your ability to properly execute this workout. The majority of this workout is done in heart rate Z1/2 /// 50-75% of threshold /// RPE 2-5. You should keep the effort level below threshold (heart rate Z4, 100% of threshold, RPE 7-8) during the max cadence efforts.

​

WORKOUT GOALS:

- To improve stillness and stability at high cadences.
- To improve muscle fiber engagement for improved efficiency at all cadences.
- To increase maximum cadence.
- To make that pedal stroke as smooth as butter.

CADENCE TARGETS:

- Warm-up 80-90rpm
- Build: 90-150rpm
- Hold: 115rpm
- Single Leg: 85rpm

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

​

**Warm Up**

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <70%

3 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 3

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 23 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval Repeats Per Set: N/A

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Cadence Hold: 45 seconds @ RPE 7.5 -- <100% FTP -- Highest RPM you can hold without Bouncing

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Recovery: 1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

Single Leg: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- Single Leg Only, Opposite Leg -- <50% of FTP (100% of FTP with both legs = 50% of FTP

with one leg)

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Coll de Rates
prospects.description:
This session is all about building your VO₂ Max power with a focus on pacing. You’ll start with a flat warm-up to get the body ready before diving into a progressive series of ramping intervals. Each interval gets shorter but more intense, pushing your cardiovascular system while keeping your legs working under control. The aim is to help you finish strong — not fade — by learning how to pace properly through effort buildup.

​

Set on the steady slopes of Coll de Rates, the consistent gradient supports rhythm and control, allowing you to focus on cadence, breathing, and technique as you go deeper into the red. The final threshold block adds bonus training stimulus and flushes the legs under fatigue. This is a session that builds smarter, stronger climbers — from both a physical and mental standpoint.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/14035783847)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tempo Alternating: 1 x 20
prospects.description:
This short, 36-minute workout will get you in and out of Sufferlandria in no time, with a solid 20 minute tempo block to boot. This continuous tempo effort will have you alternate between 75 & 85% of FTP every minute. Not only does this help pass the time rather quickly, it will help improve your aerobic fitness. Time spent in this intensity range will help increase your stroke volume (amount of blood your heart can pump every minute), your lactate threshold, and the mitochondrial density of your muscles (mitochondria are the "power houses" of the cells that create energy). All of these things are very important parts of aerobic metabolism and performing your best- especially if you like group rides. This is the typical intensity range that most group rides fall into- not a leisurely pace, but not so fast that people are falling off the back within minutes. So if you find that you commonly struggle with group rides, gradually spending more time on workouts at this intensity will have you holding on longer and taking your pulls without missing a beat!

​

**Warm Up**

6 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 10

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

Work: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

Steady: 1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

N/A

prospects.name: The Chores
prospects.description:
If you want a do-it-all session that will maintain and improve nearly every aspect of your fitness, _The Chores_ is just the ticket. This workout features 3 sets of intervals. Each set combines a series of 40-second efforts with 20-second recoveries, followed by an immediate transition to a sustained effort just below threshold. These short efforts with minimal recovery deplete your anaerobic gas tank, forcing your body to get better at producing power aerobically. This combination will help improve your Anaerobic Capacity, (AC) your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and your Functional Threshold Power (FTP), all in just under an hour.

​

At the start of each set, your body starts to dip into your anaerobic reserves to help hit the high-power targets. Your body then starts to ramp up your oxygen intake in order to produce more of the power requirements aerobically. With such short recovery time between these efforts, your AC is steadily drained through each set. By the time the last short interval arrives, your body will be forced to produce almost all of that power aerobically, which will push your lungs to their very limit.

​

This is the optimal time to stress your body’s ability to produce power at threshold. With your AC depleted (and your lungs and heart working near maximal capacity), the shorter sustained efforts that would normally be a piece of cake will have a bit more...sting. No matter what your preferred discipline, terrain, or distance, this session will make you fitter and faster.

​

Featuring exciting, on-bike camera footage from the Velon Hammer Series, _The Chores_ will make you earn your keep.

prospects.name: Sub-Threshold with Starting Surge: 3 x 10
prospects.description:
The idea behind this session can be seen in Who Dares, Fight Club, and Standing Starts into sustained efforts. Your bodies ability to clear out metabolites and process oxygen is nearly identical between 90% of FTP and 100% of FTP, the difference is that at 100% of FTP your body is producing those metabolites at the same rate it is clearing them. At 90% of FTP your body can clear things at the same rate, but your body isn't producing them at the same rate.

Long Sub-Threshold efforts represent an effort that your body can just about handle (assuming you are properly fueled and not completely exhausted), clearing things out faster than they can accumulate. To really stress that clearance rate each of these Sub-Threshold efforts start with a 20-second effort well above FTP. By the time you settle into the Sub-Threshold effort, your body will be flooded with those metabolites that cause your legs and lungs to burn. However, since you are below FTP (clearing things out faster than you are producing them), the concentration of those metabolites will slowly drop over the course of the whole effort. Not only does this train your body to clear things faster, but it will also mentally prepare for the discomfort associated with efforts above FTP.

​

For this session, we are asking you to dance on that razor's edge of your FTP, ideally the side that allows you to complete the session. If your legs or lungs aren't feeling great, you are better off dropping the steady effort by 5% and keeping the starting effort at 100%. Another component of this is settling into a good rhythm of breathing and pedaling. Everyone has a preferred cadence, and this is an instance where your preferred cadence supersedes the cadence targets onscreen. We want you dancing right on that edge of your comfort, and you can get much closer to that edge riding your preferred cadence.

​

**Warm Up**

20 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

1 minute @ RPE 5.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <90%

30 seconds @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

30 seconds @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

6 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: NA

**Interval**

20 seconds @ RPE 9.5 -- 180% of FTP -- HR >105%

10 minutes @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

25 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: The Cure
prospects.description:
Do you have Couchlandrian Tendencies? This short but powerful workout will cure you of that affliction and reassert your inner Sufferlandrian. The session is based on a combination of specific micro-intervals (made famous by Japanese coach and physiologist Izumi Tabata) that we combined with classic tempo efforts. This gives you a superb mix of Anaerobic Capacity (AC), Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and FTP training stresses in one short workout to help you go faster and stay stronger for longer.

​

Now, for the sports science purists among you, the 'Tabata' intervals should actually be named 'Koichi' intervals, since it was Japanese speedskating coach Irisawa Koichi who first employed the use of the 20-seconds on / 10-seconds off intervals that Dr. Izumi then confirmed via physiology lab studies to yield the best mix of maximal aerobic and anaerobic stress among the different on/off protocols that he tested.

​

For this workout, we have toned down the original intensity of the Tabata intervals to target MAP rather than Anaerobic Capacity in order to be able to complete the 20/10 micro-intervals and then follow the short efforts immediately with sustained 80-100% of FTP intervals to replicate the kind of attack and then settle efforts that are common in cycling races.

​

From a physiological perspective, you’ll produce lots of lactate during the micro-intervals. Then the goal of the tempo and FTP efforts is to stress your body’s capacity to clear that lactate as quickly as possible. Effectively, we’re trying to maximize lactate 'flux.' For each successive round of the efforts, you’ll do one less micro-interval, and the tempo efforts will get shorter. But because you’re a Sufferlandrian, they won’t get easier, and the rest between sets will get shorter. The intensity for the tempo efforts will ramp up with each repetition. Fortunately for you, there are only 3 sets of efforts and you’ll be done in just 30 minutes. If you’ve set aside an hour for this workout, you’ll be happy to have those additional 30 minutes for recovery after this session.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Endurance 1.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 4

**Interval**

10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

**Extra Volume**

NA

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: The Other French Race
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Rupert Guinness entered the Haute Route Alps in France looking for a new challenge to test his physical and mental strength. But after 800km of cycling through the Alps from Nice to Megève, the cycling journalist and author realized that the experience had delivered to him and the 400-plus starters something far greater. It had provided them with the adventure of a lifetime; from a sense of what it would be like to ride in the fabled Tour de France that he has reported on more than 30 times, to the creation of friendships with fellow riders forged by their shared suffering and encouragement for one another as they cycled through some of the toughest and most spectacular mountains that cycling has to offer.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Openers
prospects.description:
Whether you have power testing, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. The key to this session is just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

​

**Warm-Up**

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

1 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-190% of FTP)

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3, all unique

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

**Set 1**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 3 minutes at @ RPE 7 -- 90% of FTP --HR <95%

**Set 2**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

**Set 3**

Interval Repeats per set: 3

Interval: Effort: 30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 95% of MAP (110-130% of FTP)

Recovery: 90 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

6 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP

prospects.description:
Go crush your SBT Ride!

​

Don't forget to download the route from the [website](https://www.sbtgrvl.com/2024courses).

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Breathing More Deeply
prospects.description: Diaphragmatic Breathing is a calming exercise that encourages you to breathe deeply into your abdomen. This can help improve your ability to take in oxygen on the bike, as well as help you stay calm on focused when the pressure is on.

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them
prospects.description: This is the breathing technique used by Navy Seals to help them focus and find calm before major operations. Learn and use this technique before heading into your own major events and races.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose
